results.title: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Triandafyllidis, Iraklis Mavroidis, Amanda Livanou, Fenia Cossovista, Astra and Ideefixe
results.brief_description: Screamin’ Jay Hawkins (1929-2000) was a unique Afro-American musician who had a tumultuous career and a strong affiliation with voodoo. He was renowned for his eccentric live performances - emerging out of coffins on stage, and laying bones, skulls and other paraphernalia atop his piano. Along with Bo Didley, Hawkins celebrated his blackness in a way that was very rare in the 1950s and frequently alluded to jungles, cannibalism and mysticism to a degree that even alienated his black audience. Hawkins fame was much diminished when his song “I put a spell on you” was used in the Jim Jarmusch cult film “Stranger than paradise” but Hawkins had lost the rights to the song, receiving few royalties from its massive success. Jarmusch also cast Hawkins as a desk clerk in “Mystery train” (1989). This documentary features interviews with Bo Didley, Diamanda Galas, Jim Jarmusch, Andrew Williams and Eric Burden as well as producers, family and friends. Songs include: I put a spell on you (several versions), Alligator wine, Frenzy, Shout and Goodnight sweetheart. Features live footage of Hawkins on stage as well as extensive interviews with him just prior to his death.

results.title: Science international. No. 1. What is life?
results.creator_credit: Aubrey F Singer, Humphrey Fisher and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A report on the world-wide investigation into the origins of life, as revealed in the study of the cell, and progress in the battle against cancer. Explains what is known of the nature, operation, and origin of the living human cell. Interviews and demonstrations involve scientists from Britain, the United States, France and the Soviet Union. Extensive use is made of a model of a living cell enlarged a million times.

results.title: Scream greats. Vol. 01: Tom Savini, master of horror make-up (D)
results.creator_credit: Damon Santostefano, Linda Laias and O'Quinn Productions
results.brief_description: Tom Savini who has acted and performed stunts for Hollywood productions is mostly known for his blood-curdling special effects used in horror films. “Scream greats” takes a close look at the life, influences and techniques in ‘horror’ special effects that Tom Savini brought to the screen. Tom Savini is reputed to have caused the explosion in popularity of horror films since the eighties as a result of his increasingly realistic and gory special effects devised for these films. Featured are interviews with Tom and other colleagues along with excerpts from some of the horror films in which Savini’s special effects and make-up design were central to the film, including: “Friday the 13th” series, “Day of the dead”, “Martin”, “Dawn of the dead”, “Knight riders”, “Maniac”, “Tales from the darkside” plus more.

results.title: Science in a wine glass
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Shows in detail, through specially made glass tanks, how wine is fermented, how fermentation is arrested, how color is infused into the red wine from skin pigmentation, how champagne is made and how wine matures. Also demonstrates how cross-pollination is effected to produce new varieties of grapes.

results.title: Scream 2
results.creator_credit: Wes Craven, Marianne Maddalena, Cathy Konrad and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: The first ‘Scream’ (308434) was a clever genre deconstruction of the do’s and dont’s of the teen slasher film, so it’s not so surprising then that ‘Scream 2’ pays clever homage to sequels. Like all good horror sequels the body count is higher, the murders are more gruesome, but contrary to the belief held by the film literate teens in this film that “sequels suck”, ‘Scream 2’ pleasingly holds its own. It even has it’s own film within a film, “Stab”, the movie version of the events of the first film. This time round, Sydney Prescott (Neve Campbell reprising her role) is at college trying to put the Woodsboro murders behind her, that is until a series of campus murders aping the killings of the first film make it clear that someone is planning a sequel of their own. Director Wes Craven, (no slouch to the genre himself having made ‘Nightmare on Elm St’ and ‘The Hills have Eyes’) and writer Kevin Williamson inject fresh ‘blood’ into the formula by presenting a group of characters to care for (not just a bunch of disposable, horny teens), and by not sacrificing the frights for the sake of a cheap laugh, a common malady of contemporary horror. Cast includes David Arquette, Courtney Cox, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Heather Graham, Jamie Kennedy, Laurie Metcalf, Jerry O’Connell, Liev Schreiber and Jada Pinkett.

results.title: Scream
results.creator_credit: Wes Craven, Cathy Konrad, Cary Woods and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Sidney Prescott (Neve Campbell) is a teenager struggling through life with a boyfriend (Skeet Ulrich) not content with their present sex life, a father who is constantly absent on business trips, and the approaching one year anniversary of her mother’s brutal murder. Just as things seem to be getting back to normal for Sidney and her friends, the small town of Woodsboro is once again plauged by a crazed killer who is turning the formula plot of horror movies into reality. Also starring David Arquette, Courteney Cox, Matthew Lillard and Rose McGowan.

results.title: Science fiction: Jules Verne to Ray Bradbury... and beyond
results.creator_credit: Barbara Winard and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: The three parts of these videos give a brief overview of science fiction through history. Clips from films and television programs are used as illustrations. “From Lucian to Jules Verne” traces the beginnings of science fiction in social satire and criticism with the works of Lucian, Thomas More and Swift until Jules Verne revived the genre by tapping into scientific possibilities. “From H. G. Wells to George Orwell” shows how H. G. Wells linked the old and the new science fiction writers, who developed the space opera, magazines, and the science fiction film, culminating in Orwell’s grim visions of the future. “From Isaac Asimov to Arthur C. Clarke” documents the influences of outside factors such as World War II, the cold war, Vietnam and the hippy experience of the 60’s in the works of Asimov, Heinlein, Herbert and Clarke. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.
